# ğŸ… <b>Part Aï¼šå¿…è€ƒæ¦‚å¿µé¢˜ï¼ˆé«˜æ¦‚ç‡ + æ ‡å‡†è‹±æ–‡ç­”æ¡ˆï¼‰</b>

---

## <b>Q1. Define support and confidence in association rule mining.</b>

### <b>Standard Answer</b>

Support measures how frequently an itemset appears in the transactional database.  

\[

\text{support}(A) = \frac{\#\text{transactions containing } A}{n}

\]

Confidence measures the empirical conditional probability of the rule \(A \rightarrow B\).  

\[

\text{confidence}(A \rightarrow B) = \frac{\text{support}(A \cup B)}{\text{support}(A)}

\]

---

## <b>Q2. What is a frequent itemset?</b>

### <b>Standard Answer</b>

A frequent itemset is an itemset whose support is greater than or equal to a predefined minimum support threshold \(S_{\min}\).  

It represents item combinations that appear sufficiently often in the database.

---

## <b>Q3. State the Apriori principle. Why is it useful?</b>

### <b>Standard Answer</b>

The Apriori principle states that:

> If an itemset is frequent, then all of its nonâ€‘empty subsets must also be frequent.

This property allows us to prune the search space by eliminating candidate itemsets whose subsets are not frequent, significantly reducing computational cost.

---

## <b>Q4. What is the difference between frequent itemset mining and association rule mining?</b>

### <b>Standard Answer</b>

Frequent itemset mining identifies itemsets that appear frequently in the database.  

Association rule mining uses these frequent itemsets to generate rules that describe conditional relationships between items, typically evaluated using support and confidence.

---

# ğŸ…‘ <b>Part Bï¼šæ‰‹ç®—é¢˜ï¼ˆæœ€å¯èƒ½è€ƒï¼‰</b>

æˆ‘ç»™ä½ å‡†å¤‡ä¸€ä¸ª<b>å’Œè¯¾å ‚ä¾‹å­éå¸¸æ¥è¿‘</b>çš„é¢˜ç›®ï¼Œè€å¸ˆæœ€å–œæ¬¢è¿™ç§ã€‚

---

## <b>Q5. Given the following transactions, compute the support of each 1â€‘itemset.</b>

Transactions:

<table>
<colgroup>
<col width="200"/>
<col width="200"/>
</colgroup>
<tbody>
<tr><td><p>TID</p></td><td><p>Items</p></td></tr>
<tr><td><p>1</p></td><td><p>A, B</p></td></tr>
<tr><td><p>2</p></td><td><p>A, C</p></td></tr>
<tr><td><p>3</p></td><td><p>B, C</p></td></tr>
<tr><td><p>4</p></td><td><p>A, B, C</p></td></tr>
<tr><td><p>5</p></td><td><p>A</p></td></tr>
</tbody>
</table>

### <b>Standard Answer</b>

Total transactions \(n = 5\).

- support(A) = 4/5 = <b>0.8</b>  
- support(B) = 3/5 = <b>0.6</b>  
- support(C) = 3/5 = <b>0.6</b>
    
---

## <b>Q6. For the same database, compute support of itemsets {A,B}, {A,C}, {B,C}.</b>

### <b>Standard Answer</b>

- support({A,B}) = 2/5 = <b>0.4</b>  
- support({A,C}) = 2/5 = <b>0.4</b>  
- support({B,C}) = 2/5 = <b>0.4</b>
    
---

## <b>Q7. Compute the confidence of the rule A â†’ B.</b>

### <b>Standard Answer</b>

\[

\text{confidence}(A \rightarrow B) = \frac{\text{support}(A \cup B)}{\text{support}(A)} = \frac{0.4}{0.8} = 0.5

\]

---

## <b>Q8. Determine all frequent itemsets for \(S_{\min} = 0.4\).</b>

### <b>Standard Answer</b>

Frequent 1â€‘itemsets:  

A (0.8), B (0.6), C (0.6)

Frequent 2â€‘itemsets:  

{A,B}, {A,C}, {B,C} (all 0.4)

Frequent 3â€‘itemset:  

{A,B,C} appears in 1/5 = 0.2 â†’ <b>not frequent</b>

Final frequent itemsets:  

\[

\{A\}, \{B\}, \{C\}, \{A,B\}, \{A,C\}, \{B,C\}

\]

---

# ğŸ…’ <b>Part Cï¼šApriori ç®—æ³•æµç¨‹é¢˜ï¼ˆæœ€å¯èƒ½çš„å¤§é¢˜ï¼‰</b>

---

## <b>Q9. Using Apriori, generate C2 and F2 from the frequent 1â€‘itemsets F1 = {A, B, C}. Assume Smin = 0.4.</b>

### <b>Standard Answer</b>

### Step 1: Generate C2

All 2â€‘combinations of F1:

\[

C_2 = \{\{A,B\}, \{A,C\}, \{B,C\}\}

\]

### Step 2: Compute support

(Using earlier results)

All three have support = 0.4.

### Step 3: Determine F2

Since all supports â‰¥ 0.4:

\[

F_2 = C_2 = \{\{A,B\}, \{A,C\}, \{B,C\}\}

\]

---

## <b>Q10. Using F2, generate C3 and determine whether any 3â€‘itemset is frequent.</b>

### <b>Standard Answer</b>

### Step 1: Join step

Only one possible 3â€‘itemset:

\[

C_3 = \{\{A,B,C\}\}

\]

### Step 2: Prune step

Check all 2â€‘subsets:

- {A,B} frequent  
- {A,C} frequent  
- {B,C} frequent  
    
â†’ All subsets frequent â†’ keep {A,B,C}

### Step 3: Compute support

support({A,B,C}) = 1/5 = 0.2 &lt; 0.4 â†’ not frequent

### Final result

\[

F_3 = \emptyset

\]

---

# ğŸ…“ <b>Part Dï¼šç»¼åˆåº”ç”¨é¢˜ï¼ˆè€å¸ˆæœ€å–œæ¬¢ï¼‰</b>

---

## <b>Q11. Given a transactional database and thresholds Smin = 0.3, Cmin = 0.6, find all strong rules from the frequent itemsets:</b>

Frequent itemsets:

- {A}: 0.7  
- {B}: 0.5  
- {C}: 0.4  
- {A,B}: 0.4  
- {A,C}: 0.3  
- {B,C}: 0.3  
    
### <b>Standard Answer</b>

### Step 1: Generate rules from 2â€‘itemsets

#### From {A,B}:

- A â†’ B: conf = 0.4 / 0.7 â‰ˆ 0.57 (not strong)
- B â†’ A: conf = 0.4 / 0.5 = 0.8 (<b>strong</b>)
    
#### From {A,C}:

- A â†’ C: 0.3 / 0.7 â‰ˆ 0.43 (not strong)
- C â†’ A: 0.3 / 0.4 = 0.75 (<b>strong</b>)
    
#### From {B,C}:

- B â†’ C: 0.3 / 0.5 = 0.6 (<b>strong</b>)
- C â†’ B: 0.3 / 0.4 = 0.75 (<b>strong</b>)
    
### <b>Final strong rules</b>

1. B â†’ A  
2. C â†’ A  
3. B â†’ C  
4. C â†’ B  
    
---

- support / confidence å®šä¹‰  
- frequent itemset å®šä¹‰  
- strong rule æ¡ä»¶  
- Apriori principle  
- Apriori çš„ generate + prune æµç¨‹

- support è®¡ç®—  
- confidence è®¡ç®—  
- frequent itemset åˆ¤æ–­  
- strong rule åˆ¤æ–­  
    
## <b>Aprioriï¼ˆ20â€“30%ï¼‰</b>

- ç»™ F1 â†’ ç”Ÿæˆ C2 â†’ F2 â†’ C3  
- åˆ¤æ–­å“ªäº› itemset è¢«å‰ªæ  
- æ‰‹ç®—ä¸€ä¸ªå°å‹æ•°æ®åº“  
    
ä½ ç°åœ¨å·²ç»æœ‰ä¸€æ•´å¥—â€œå¯ç›´æ¥å†™è¿›è€ƒè¯•â€çš„ç­”æ¡ˆã€‚

å¦‚æœä½ æ„¿æ„ï¼Œæˆ‘è¿˜èƒ½å¸®ä½ ï¼š
